node.title: ‘It felt like a wedding,’ says a refugee Francis brought to Rome from Lesbos in 2016.
node.alt: Wafaa Eid, center, and her husband, Osama Kawkji, center right, and their children were among the 12 Syrians who flew with Pope Francis to Rome from Greece in 2016.
node.description: Three Syrian families who traveled on the papal plane after the pope’s last visit to the Greek island have made new lives for themselves in Italy’s capital.
node.content: ["After Pope Francis visited the Greek island of Lesbos in April 2016, he took 12 Muslim refugees from Syria, including six children, with him back to Rome aboard the papal plane. It was an act that punctuated his pleas for sympathy toward refugees just as European attitudes were hardening against them.", "Five years later, the three families who traveled with Francis \u2014 two from Damascus and one from Deir al-Zour \u2014 have made lives for themselves in Rome, though they say that their thoughts are constantly with those they left behind in Syria.", "\u201cWhen we got on that plane with him, we felt a sense of peace that we hadn\u2019t felt for a very long time,\u201d said Wafaa Eid, 35, recalling a \u201cdreamlike\u201d trip that swept them from years of war in Syria and a fraught five-month journey to reach Europe, to a rousing welcome offered by a Catholic charity in Rome.", "\u201cThere were flowers and music \u2014 it felt like a wedding,\u201d she said. \u201cIt was great.\u201d", "Adapting to a new life, a new culture, has not always been easy, she said, but her family has found support and generosity in Rome. Both she and her husband, Osama Kawkji, 42, work in a vacation home run by a religious congregation in Rome, and their children \u2014\u00a0Masa, 13, and Omar, 11 \u2014 are in middle school in the city.", "\u201cWhenever I\u2019ve asked for help, people have reached out,\u201d she said, including parents of her children\u2019s friends and volunteers from the charity that helped them when they first arrived. She also said they had made \u201cmany Italian friends.\u201d", "All three families \u201chave settled in very well,\u201d said Cecilia Pani, who coordinates migration projects for the Community of St. Egidio charity, which works with vulnerable people in Rome and elsewhere. She was in Lesbos in 2016 to assist the families who traveled on the papal flight and has also helped them in Rome.", "She said they had been able to find jobs and housing that allow them to live independently.", "With other churches, charities and nongovernmental organizations, St. Egidio has helped facilitate the arrival to Italy of more than 3,600 refugees over the past five years.", "Learning Italian has come easily to Ms. Eid, who taught herself using her son\u2019s elementary school books.", "\u201cI studied, and then I would help him,\u201d she said.", "Work also helped. Before starting at the vacation home, she worked as a cleaner in a Rome hospital.", "One way or the other, she said of the language, \u201cI had to learn.\u201d", "In July, her family moved to a new apartment, where they live with their cat, Lulu. In the fall, the children started at a new school, where they said they liked their classes \u2014 when bouts of coronavirus among classmates didn\u2019t keep them at home.", "Asked whether he was happy living in Rome, Mr. Kawjki seemed surprised.", "\u201cYes, of course,\u201d he said. \u201cOtherwise we wouldn\u2019t stay.\u201d"]
